TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   A 68 year old gentleman was transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] (scheduled for floor
   admission) from [**Hospital 11374**] Community Hospital at the request of his
   family for ongoing pneumonia not improving with Abx.  There was also
   being treated for afib, ?CHF  and possible UE DVT. Head CT normal
   there.  Echo there with ? TV vegetation, normal EF.  During the Medivac
   (per flow sheet): patient ambulatory prior to flight.  During the
   flight he was in Afib, satting 96-100% on 3L NC.  Never hypotensive or
   tachycardic. BS varied from 81-441 (pre/post dextrose administration).
   Patient became confused ~16:15. His rate increased to 110-130  ~ 17:00,
   labelled as ? for which he received 100mg Lidocaine, presumably IV just
   prior to arrival at [**Hospital1 1**].  After deplaning from a medivac flight, the
   patient became unresponsive and was transferred to the [**Hospital1 1**] emergency
   room.
   In the ED, vital signs were initially: 96.9 69 180/84 12 100% NRB.
   Patient was intubated for airway protection given unresponsiveness
   (Etomidate & Succ for intubation; Propofol for sedation).  He was given
   Vanc/Zosyn for HAP vs. abdominal process. BS in the 70s, given D50
   without change in mental status.  Transferred to the MICU: 96.4 120/59
   14 100% 500/14/10/1.0.
   On arrival to the floor, the patient is not responsive to voice or
   sternal rub.  His family is present and confirm the hospital course.
   Per all reports, he was independent at home and still working but
   "slowing down" recently with weight loss, several recent
   hospitalizations for pneumonia.  His rapid change in status today was
   unexpected and not at all resembling his recent hospital course.
   24 Hour Events:

   suspicious for malignancy, consider MRI for further eval.
   Assessment and Plan
   A 68 yo gentleman with progressive decline transferred from [**Location (un) 11374**]
   after PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status during/after
   [**Location (un) 1045**].
   .
   #. Altered Mental Status: The patient has underlying dementia as
   evidenced by family &  recent notes. His acute decline midflight
   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine
   administration.  Seizure vs. anoxic brain injury at altitude/arrythmia,
   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently
   improving, making anoxic injury less likely.
   - lighten sedation
   - Echo to eval vegitation/clot
   - LP if no improvement
   - Obtain OSH CSF results
   - TSH normal
   - plan to extubated if no need for TEE
   .
   #. PNA: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a
   presumed aspiration PNA over the past 2 weeks. Not febrile, no
   leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet
   cleared.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn now
   - plan to extubated once clear that TEE not needed
   - Blood Cx, Sputum Cx
   - F/U OSH Micro
   - legionella urinary antigen negative
   .
   #. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired
   shivering given mental status. Now improved
   - Warming blanket overnight, now off
   - Cultures as above
   .
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure"
   based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure.
   - Fluid rescusitation
   - Monitor UOP, which is currently improved
   .
   #. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars, but has been
   requiring glucose for hypoglycemia overnight
   - Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN
   - Tube feeds
   .
   #. ? RUE DVT: Currently therpeutic INR, U/S results not in records
   - Obtain outside records
   - Repeat RUE U/S
   - Transition to heparin drip if INR <2
   .
   #. Sick Sinus: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate controlled
   without medications, received Lidocaine in transit.
   - Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled (currently in 60
   - Cardiac Enzymes, 3^rd set today
   -continue ASA
   #? Cardiac valve vegetation:  seen at OSH, and on CT here.  Getting TTE
   today.  Unclear if infected vegetation vs other cause (clot,
   neoplasm).  Will follow up TTE to eval if needs TEE.  Follow up blood
   cultures.
   #. Cerebral Ventricular Dilitation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain
   further symptom history from family.  MS currently improved from
   yesterday
   .
   #. G-tube placement for ? esophagitis:  Will contact team in [**Name (NI) 490**]
   re: need for G-tube, in patient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal
   issues, speech and swallow once awake.
   - start Tube feeds, nutrition recs
   -clarify degree of esophagitis
   .
   #. Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency
   - Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear
   # liver lesion on CT:  no acute issue.  Will follow up with MRI when
   clinically stable
   .
   #. CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves
   - Hold metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypertension: Borderline BPs
   - Hold lisinopril/metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO Daily
   .
   #. Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds
   .
   # FEN: IVFs / replete lytes prn / tube feeds
   # PPX: H2 blocker, Therapeutic Coumadin & boots, bowel regimen
   # ACCESS: PIV x2
   # CODE:  Full, discussed with patient's wife
   # CONTACT:  Wife [**Name (NI) 11376**] C: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11377**], H (daughter): [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11378**];
   H: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11379**]
   # ICU CONSENT: Signed
   # DISPOSITION:
    [X] ICU
   Total time spent:  45 min

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department due to a rapid decline in mental status during a medivac flight. He has a history of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible chronic heart failure. Upon arrival, he was intubated for airway protection and received various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and anticoagulants. He has been diagnosed with altered mental status, pneumonia, hypothermia, metabolic alkalosis, diabetes mellitus, and possible right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis. He is currently receiving tube feeds and has a gastrostomy tube in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure or anoxic brain injury: The patient's acute decline in mental status during the flight may be related to a seizure or anoxic brain injury, which could have long-term consequences.
2. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and possible right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis increase his risk of developing an infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Heart failure: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and possible chronic heart failure increase his risk of developing heart failure, which could lead to cardiogenic shock and death.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and possible aspiration could lead to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation and increase his risk of mortality.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of chronic pancreatitis and possible esophagitis increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hemodynamic instability and death.
6. Thromboembolic events: The patient's possible right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis increase his risk of developing thromboembolic events, such as pulmonary embolism, which could lead to respiratory failure and death.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient's diabetes mellitus and possible hypothyroidism increase his risk of developing metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia and hypokalemia, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and death.
8. Infection-related complications: The patient's infection and possible sepsis could lead to infection-related complications, such as organ failure and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and possible aspiration.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and sedation level closely.
3. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider mechanical ventilation if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider tube feeds and nutrition recommendations.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider cardiology consultation.
7. Monitor the patient's metabolic status and consider endocrinology consultation.
8. Monitor the patient's infection status and consider infectious disease consultation.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 68 yo gentleman with progressive decline transferred from [**Location (un) 11374**]
   after PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status during/after
   [**Location (un) 1045**].
   .
   #. Altered Mental Status: The patient has underlying dementia as
   evidenced by family &  recent notes. His acute decline midflight
   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine
   administration.  Seizure vs. anoxic brain injury at altitude/arrythmia,
   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently
   unresponsive and intubated for airway protection.
   - Daily wake up to assess mental status
   - EEG in AM
   - Echo to eval vegitation/clot
   - LP if no improvement
   - Obtain OSH CSF results
   - TSH
   - Check Ammonia
   .
   #. PNA: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a
   presumed aspiration PNA over the past 2 weeks. Not febrile, no
   leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet
   cleared.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn now
   - Respiratory support as above until mental status clears
   - Blood Cx, Sputum Cx
   - F/U OSH Micro
   - Add on legionella urinary antigen
   .
   #. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired
   shivering given mental status.
   - Warming blanket
   - Cultures
   .
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure"
   based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure.  No
   exposure to steroids, unable to compensate because of mechanical
   ventilation.
   - Permissive hypercapnia
   - Fluid rescusitation
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   #. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars
   - Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN
   - Tube feeds
   .
   #. ? RUE DVT: Currently therpeutic INR, U/S results not in records
   - Obtain outside records
   - Repeat RUE U/S
   - Transition to heparin drip if INR <2
   .
   #. Sick Sinus: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate controlled
   without medications, received Lidocaine in transit.
   - Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled
   - Cardiac Enzymes
   .
   #. Ventricular Dilitation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain further
   symptom history from family.
   .
   #. G-tube placement for ? esophagitis:  Will contact team in [**Name (NI) 490**]
   re: need for G-tube, in patient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal
   issues, speech and swallow once awake.
   - start Tube feeds, nutrition recs
   .
   #. Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency
   - Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear
   .
   #. CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves
   - Hold metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypertension: Borderline BPs
   - Hold lisinopril/metoprolol
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO Daily
   .
   #. Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency room after experiencing a sudden decline in mental status during a medivac flight. The patient has a history of pneumonia, and his recent hospital course has been complicated by multiple hospitalizations.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* He is intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status.
* He has a rapid ventricular rate and is receiving lidocaine for rate control.
* He has a history of atrial flutter and is currently paced.
* He has a borderline blood pressure and is receiving anticoagulation therapy.
* He has a history of chronic pancreatitis and is receiving Creon with meals and tube feeds.
* He has a history of diabetes mellitus and is receiving tube feeds with dextrose supplementation.
* He has a history of hypertension and is receiving antihypertensive medication.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Seizure or anoxic brain injury due to the patient's altered mental status and rapid ventricular rate.
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's pneumonia and potential source of infection.
* Hypothyroidism or metabolic alkalosis due to the patient's recent diuresis and potential impaired shivering.
* Diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperglycemia due to the patient's history of diabetes mellitus and variable blood sugars.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to the patient's history of atrial flutter and anticoagulation therapy.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to the patient's history of chronic pancreatitis and potential esophageal issues.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Daily wake-up to assess mental status.
* EEG in the morning to evaluate for seizure or anoxic brain injury.
* Echo to evaluate for clot or septic emboli showering from potential vegetation.
* LP if no improvement in mental status.
* Obtain OSH CSF results.
* TSH to evaluate for hypothyroidism.
* Check ammonia levels.
* Continue Vanc/Zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA.
* Respiratory support as above until mental status clears.
* Blood cultures and sputum cultures.
* F/U OSH micro.
* Add on legionella urinary antigen.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department due to acute changes in mental status, including becoming unresponsive and confused. He was previously treated for pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible pulmonary embolism.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered mental status: The patient has underlying dementia, and his acute decline mid-flight appears to correspond to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine administration. Seizure, anoxic brain injury, or clot/septic emboli showering from a possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve are possible causes.
* Pneumonia: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a presumed aspiration pneumonia over the past two weeks. Not febrile, no leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet cleared.
* Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired shivering given mental status. Now improved.
* Metabolic alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure" based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure. Fluid resuscitation and monitoring of urine output are recommended.
* Diabetes mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars, but has been requiring glucose for hypoglycemia overnight. Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN, and tube feeds are recommended.
* Possible right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Currently therapeutic INR, ultrasound results not in records. Obtain outside records, repeat RUE ultrasound, and transition to heparin drip if INR < 2.
* Sick sinus syndrome: Paced, currently anticoagulated and rate controlled without medications, received lidocaine in transit. Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled, and continue ASA.
* Cardiac valve vegetation: Seen at outside hospital and on CT here. Unclear if infected vegetation vs. other cause (clot, neoplasm). Will follow up TTE to evaluate if needs TEE and follow up blood cultures.
* Cerebral ventricular dilation: Possible NPH as cause, will obtain further symptom history from family. MS currently improved from yesterday.
* G-tube placement for possible esophagitis: Will contact team in [**Name (NI) 490**] re: need for G-tube, inpatient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal issues, speech, and swallow once awake.
* Anemia: ACD vs. Iron deficiency. Iron, B12, Folate, Retic count, smear are recommended.
* CAD: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves. Hold metoprolol.
* Hypertension: Borderline BPs. Hold lisinopril/metoprolol.
* Hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO daily.
* Chronic pancreatitis: Creon with meals/tube feeds.
* FEN: IVFs/replete lytes prn/tube feeds.
* PPX: H2 blocker, therapeutic Coumadin & boots, bowel regimen.
* ACCESS: PIV x2.
* CODE: Full, discussed with patient's wife.
* CONTACT: Wife [**Name (NI) 11376**] C: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11377**], H (daughter): [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11378**]; H: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11379**].
* ICU CONSENT: Signed.
* DISPOSITION: ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis or septic shock due to possible pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, or cardiac valve vegetation.
2. Anoxic brain injury or cerebral edema due to prolonged hypoxia or hypotension.
3. Ventricular arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to cardiac valve vegetation, atrial fibrillation, or sick sinus syndrome.
4. Respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to pneumonia or cardiac valve vegetation.
5. Renal failure or acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis, hypovolemia, or cardiac failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to esophagitis or chronic pancreatitis.
7. Hyperglycemic or hypoglycemic crises due to diabetes mellitus.
8. Bleeding complications due to anticoagulation therapy or liver dysfunction.
9. Cardiac failure or cardiogenic shock due to cardiac valve vegetation, atrial fibrillation, or sick sinus syndrome.
10. Anemia or bleeding complications due to chronic pancreatitis or gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the key information as follows:

Patient Profile:
The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for ongoing pneumonia that did not improve with antibiotics. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, possible congestive heart failure, and a possible upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Current Condition:
The patient's condition rapidly deteriorated during a medivac flight, resulting in confusion, increased heart rate, and eventual unresponsiveness. He was intubated for airway protection and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient's acute decline mid-flight is attributed to rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine administration. The differential diagnosis includes seizure, anoxic brain injury, clot or septic emboli, and possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve.
	* Plan: Daily wake-up to assess mental status, EEG in the morning, echo to evaluate vegetation/clot, and LP if no improvement.
2. Pneumonia (PNA): The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a presumed aspiration PNA over the past two weeks. He is not febrile, and the CXR findings may represent old PNA not yet cleared.
	* Plan: Continue Vanc/Zosyn, respiratory support, blood cultures, and sputum cultures.
3. Hypothermia: The patient's mental status may be related to sepsis, hypothyroidism, or impaired shivering.
	* Plan: Warming blanket, cultures, and fluid resuscitation.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's recent diuresis may be related to sepsis or heart failure, and he is unable to compensate due to mechanical ventilation.
	* Plan: Permissive hypercapnia, fluid resuscitation, and monitor urine output.
5. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's blood sugars are highly variable.
	* Plan: Reduce home Lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN, and tube feeds.
6.? RUE DVT: The patient is currently anticoagulated, and U/S results are pending.
	* Plan: Obtain outside records, repeat RUE U/S, and transition to heparin drip if INR <2.
7. Sick Sinus: The patient is paced, and his rate is controlled without medications.
	* Plan: Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate-controlled, and cardiac enzymes.
8. Ventricular Dilitation: The patient's possible NPH is being evaluated.
	* Plan: Obtain further symptom history from the family.
9. G-tube placement: The patient's possible esophagitis is being evaluated.
	* Plan: Contact the team for need for G-tube placement, inpatient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal issues, speech, and swallow once awake.
10. Anemia: The patient's anemia is being evaluated.
	* Plan: Iron, B12, folate, retic count, and smear.
11. CAD: The patient's CAD is being managed.
	* Plan: Continue ASA, restart statin as status improves, and hold metoprolol.
12. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being managed.
	* Plan: Hold lisinopril/metoprolol.
13. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is being managed.
	* Plan: Levothyroxine 150mcg PO daily.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's rapid deterioration during the medivac flight and his current condition suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's acute decline mid-flight may have caused anoxic brain injury.
3. Clot or Septic Emboli: The patient's possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve and his current condition suggest the possibility of clot or septic emboli.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's ongoing pneumonia may worsen his condition.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to his current condition.
6. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus may be contributing to his current condition.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac history and his current condition suggest the possibility of cardiac complications.

I recommend close monitoring of the patient's condition, including daily wake-up to assess mental status, EEG, echo, and LP if necessary. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be continued, and respiratory support should be maintained until his mental status improves. Additionally, the patient's fluid status, blood glucose levels, and electrolyte balance should be closely monitored.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency room with a rapid decline in mental status during a medivac flight. He has a history of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and possible chronic heart failure. On arrival, he was intubated for airway protection and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, but his mental status remains altered. He has a history of dementia, and the acute decline is thought to be related to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine administration during the flight.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient's acute decline in mental status during the flight raises concerns about anoxic brain injury.
2. Seizure: The patient's rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine administration during the flight may have triggered a seizure.
3. Septic Emboli: The patient's possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve and density in the liver suspicious for malignancy raise concerns about septic emboli.
4. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient's highly variable blood sugars and recent diuresis for "heart failure" suggest metabolic alkalosis.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's recent diagnosis of hypothyroidism and ongoing treatment with levothyroxine may be contributing to his altered mental status.
6. Chronic Pancreatitis: The patient's history of chronic pancreatitis and ongoing treatment with Creon may be related to his altered mental status.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's history of pneumonia and ongoing treatment with antibiotics may be contributing to his altered mental status.
8. Cardiac Valve Vegetation: The patient's possible vegetation on the tricuspid valve and ongoing treatment with antibiotics may be related to his altered mental status.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's altered mental status is thought to be related to a combination of factors, including his underlying dementia, rapid ventricular rate, lidocaine administration, and possible septic emboli. The plan is to lighten sedation, evaluate the vegetation on the tricuspid valve, and consider a lumbar puncture if no improvement is seen. The patient will also be monitored for signs of sepsis and treated accordingly.

   HPI:
   A 68 year old gentleman was transferred to [**Hospital1 1**] (scheduled for floor
   admission) from [**Hospital 11374**] Community Hospital at the request of his
   family for ongoing pneumonia.  During the Medivac (per flow sheet):
   patient ambulatory prior to flight.  During the flight he was in Afib,
   satting 96-100% on 3L NC.  Never hypotensive or tachycardic. BS varied
   from 81-441 (pre/post dextrose administration).  Patient became
   confused ~1615. His rate increased to 110 ~ 1700, labelled as ? for
   which he received 100mg Lidocaine, presumably IV just prior to arrival
   at [**Hospital1 1**].  After deplaning from a medivac flight, the patient became
   unresponsive and was transferred to the [**Hospital1 1**] emergency room.
   .
   In the ED, vital signs were initially: 96.9 69 180/84 12 100% NRB.
   Patient was intubated for airway protection given unresponsiveness
   (Etomidate & Succ for intubation; Propofol for sedation).  He was given

   without change in mental status.  Transferred to the MICU: 96.4 120/59

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department after being intubated for airway protection due to unresponsiveness. He was previously admitted to another hospital for pneumonia and was scheduled for floor admission. However, he rapidly deteriorated during the medivac flight, becoming confused, tachycardic, and eventually unresponsive. In the ICU, his vital signs are stable, but he remains intubated and sedated. His medical history is significant for recent hospitalizations for pneumonia, and he has a history of atrial flutter.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient develops pneumonia or has a prolonged ICU stay.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and recent hospitalizations may have triggered a systemic inflammatory response, increasing his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial flutter may be a sign of underlying cardiac disease, and there is a risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's unresponsiveness and confusion may be a sign of neurological compromise, and there is a risk of neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, or even brain death.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and recent hospitalizations may have increased his risk of developing other infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), or central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's recent hospitalizations and pneumonia may have increased his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration, bleeding, or bowel obstruction.
7. Nutritional Complications: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and lack of oral intake may lead to nutritional deficiencies, particularly if he is not receiving adequate nutrition support.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current clinical status, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and medical treatment plan to prevent and manage potential complications.

   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine
   administration.  Seizure vs. anoxic brain injury at altitude/arrythmia,
   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently
   unresponsive and intubated for airway protection.
   - Daily wake up to assess mental status

   - LP if no improvement

   - TSH
   - Check Ammonia
   #. PNA: The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for a
   presumed aspiration PNA over the past 2 weeks. Not febrile, no
   leukocytosis, possible that CXR findings represent old PNA not yet
   cleared.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn now

   - Blood Cx, Sputum Cx

   #. Hypothermia: Concern for sepsis vs. hypothyroidism vs. impaired
   shivering given mental status.
   - Warming blanket
   - Cultures
   #. Metabolic Alkalosis: Patient recently diuresed for "heart failure"
   based on CXR findings, although it is unclear he has heart failure.  No
   exposure to steroids, unable to compensate because of mechanical
   ventilation.
   - Permissive hypercapnia
   - Fluid rescusitation
   - Monitor UOP
   #. Diabetes Mellitus: Highly variable blood sugars
   - Reduce home lantus to 8, Humalog SS + dextrose PRN
   - Tube feeds
   #. ? RUE DVT: Currently therpeutic INR, U/S results not in records
   - Obtain outside records

   - Hold metoprolol/diltiazem while rate controlled

   re: need for G-tube, in patient vs. outpatient GI to address esophageal
   issues, speech and swallow once awake.
   - start Tube feeds, nutrition recs

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from a hospital with a history of progressive decline, altered mental status, and pneumonia. He has been treated with various antibiotics for a presumed aspiration pneumonia over the past two weeks. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated for endocarditis, hypoglycemia, altered mental status, and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 65 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/50 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 100%. His laboratory results show mild anemia, mild hyperglycemia, and mild electrolyte abnormalities.

The patient's imaging studies show a 13mm soft tissue density nodule on the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, concerning for infective endocarditis. He also has left upper and lower lobe pneumonia, bilateral pleural effusions, and intermediate density right renal lesions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a 13mm soft tissue density nodule on the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, which is concerning for infective endocarditis. This could lead to further cardiac complications, such as valve damage or heart failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has left upper and lower lobe pneumonia, which could lead to respiratory failure or sepsis.
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are mildly elevated, but he is at risk for hypoglycemia due to his diabetes and altered mental status.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status could be due to sepsis, hypoglycemia, or other underlying medical conditions. This could lead to further complications, such as aspiration or falls.
5. Electrolyte Abnormalities: The patient's laboratory results show mild electrolyte abnormalities, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's imaging studies show intermediate density right renal lesions, which could be indicative of kidney disease or injury.
7. Hepatic Complications: The patient's imaging studies show heterogeneous enhancement of the hepatic parenchyma, which could be indicative of liver disease or injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for endocarditis and pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and electrolyte levels closely.
3. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's cardiac, respiratory, and renal status.
4. Consider consultation with a cardiologist, pulmonologist, and nephrologist to evaluate the patient's underlying medical conditions.
5. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and consider further management of his diabetes.
6. Consider further management of his electrolyte abnormalities, such as potassium or magnesium supplementation.
7. Consider further evaluation of his liver function, such as liver function tests or imaging studies.

   appears to correspond roughly to a rapid ventricular rate and lidocaine

   clot or septic emboli showering from ? vegitation.  Currently

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has a history of progressive decline, with an acute change in mental status during/after a recent flight. He is intubated for airway protection and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 65 bpm, blood pressure of 101/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic pancreatitis. He is also taking medications for hyperthyroidism and is receiving treatment for suspected aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and troponin levels, consistent with sepsis. His blood cultures are pending, and he is receiving empiric antibiotics for presumed aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's imaging studies show a 13 mm soft tissue density nodule on the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, concerning for infective endocarditis. He also has bilateral pleural effusions, left upper and lower lobe pneumonia, and small amount of fluid layering posteriorly in the pelvis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and troponin levels suggest sepsis. He is at risk for septic shock, organ failure, and death.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's diagnosis of endocarditis puts him at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and valve damage.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's diagnosis of pneumonia puts him at risk for respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and sepsis.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status puts him at risk for neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, and death.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes mellitus and his current treatment with insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents puts him at risk for hypoglycemia.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes mellitus and his current treatment with insulin and oral hypoglycemic agents puts him at risk for hyperglycemia.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia puts him at risk for cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
8. Chronic pancreatitis: The patient's diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis puts him at risk for pancreatic complications, such as pancreatitis, pancreatic cancer, and malnutrition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric antibiotics for presumed aspiration pneumonia.
2. Perform a thorough evaluation of the patient's endocarditis, including echocardiography and blood cultures.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status and neurological function closely.
4. Manage the patient's blood sugar levels carefully to prevent hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Consider the patient's chronic pancreatitis and pancreatitis in his treatment plan.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider replacing fluids and electrolytes as necessary.
8. Consider the patient's cardiac status and monitor his cardiac function closely.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, including sepsis, endocarditis, pneumonia, altered mental status, hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, anemia, chronic pancreatitis, and cardiac complications. It is essential to monitor his condition closely and manage his treatment accordingly to prevent these complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, aspiration, and altered mental status. The patient has a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, chronic pancreatitis, and CAD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T = 36.2C, HR = 65 bpm, BP = 101/50 mmHg, RR = 15 insp/min, SpO2 = 100%
* Respiratory support: Intubated, receiving CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow ventilation, PEEP = 5 cmH2O, FiO2 = 40%
* Cardiovascular status: Paced, with a probable vegetation on the tricuspid valve
* Renal function: Creatinine = 0.7 mg/dL, BUN = 32 mg/dL
* Hepatic function: Bilirubin = 19 mg/dL, AST = 240 mg/dL, ALT = 41 mg/dL
* Coagulation profile: INR = 2.6, PTT = 40.1 seconds
* Blood glucose: 240 mg/dL
* WBC count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hb: 9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 558 K/uL

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

* Right upper extremity DVT: The patient's ultrasound did not show any evidence of DVT, but further evaluation is needed to rule out this possibility.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient has bilateral pleural effusions and may be at risk for pulmonary embolism.
* Liver lesions: The patient has heterogeneous enhancement of the hepatic parenchyma on CT scan, which may indicate perfusion or enhancing lesions.
* Biliary or hepatic neoplasm: The patient's liver lesions may be indicative of a neoplasm.
* Atherosclerotic disease: The patient has marked atherosclerotic disease, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic inflammation, which may be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia and endocarditis
* Sedation and analgesia for pain and agitation
* Vasopressors for hypotension
* Mechanical ventilation for respiratory support
* Tube feeds for nutrition
* H2 blockers for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Coumadin for anticoagulation
* Lidocaine for cardiac arrhythmia prophylaxis

The patient's disposition is currently ICU, pending further investigation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 68-year-old gentleman, was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department with a diagnosis of progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was intubated upon arrival due to hypoxemia. Overnight, he has done better and was weaned down on ventilator settings. He has a history of tricuspid valve vegetation and was noted to have atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response upon transfer.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98.1F)
* Heart rate: 65 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 101/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 79%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Not well-nourished and thin
* Cardiovascular: S2 sound is loud, but no murmur was appreciated (although a right lower sternal border systolic murmur was noted by the team)
* Respiratory: Symmetric chest expansion, crackles in the left lung base, and diminished breath sounds in the bases
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, and bowel sounds are present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema is absent, and left lower extremity edema is absent, but left upper extremity has 2+ swelling
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, and is sedated

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 28.0%
* Platelet count: 543 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Trop-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Troponin-T: 0.03 ng/mL
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies reveal:

* CT chest: Large right effusion with scattered nodules, and diffuse left consolidation
* UENIs: Negative
* Microbiology: Blood cultures are pending, and urine and sputum cultures are negative

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Acute respiratory failure: Treating empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, following up with cultures, and considering thoracentesis given the patient's history of malignancy and complicated pleural disease.
* Tricuspid vegetation: Performing a transthoracic echocardiogram today, and anticipating a prolonged course, possibly requiring involvement of the infectious disease service.
* Left upper extremity swelling: Performing an ultrasound today.
* Poss aspiration and history of erosive esophagitis: Continuing tube feeds and contacting the previous hospital to clarify the indication for gastrostomy tube placement.
* Liver lesions: Anticipating further imaging of the liver.
* CAD: Continuously administering beta blockers and aspirin, and holding statin therapy.
* Anemia: Trending hemoglobin levels and considering iron deficiency or anemia of chronic disease.
* Afib/SVT: Rate-controlling with warfarin, and monitoring INR.
* HTN: Holding antihypertensive medications and monitoring blood pressure.
* Metabolic alkalosis: Not indicating further diuresis, and supporting IV fluids for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia progression
* Tricuspid valve vegetation infection
* Aspiration pneumonia
* Liver lesions progression
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypertensive crisis
* Metabolic alkalosis worsening
* Anemia worsening
* Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to adjust his treatment plan accordingly and prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He has been treated empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.2C (97.1F)
* Heart rate: 65 bpm
* Blood pressure: 101/50 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 79%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial Flutter

The patient has a history of malignancy, complicated pleural disease, and tricuspid vegetation. He has also undergone a gastrostomy tube insertion at OSH, but the reason for this is unclear.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.1 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 28.0%
* Platelet count: 543 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 38 mmHg
* Glucose: 41 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CT chest: Large right effusion with scattered ground-glass opacities and diffuse left consolidation
* UENIs: Negative
* TTE: Unclear risk history, may need to involve ID service

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Acute respiratory failure: Treating empirically with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, checking ABG today, and assessing SBT today and considering extubation.
* Tricuspid vegetation: TTE today, unclear risk history, may need to involve ID service.
* LUE swelling: LUE ultrasound today.
* Poss aspiration and hx erosive esophagitis: S/p G-tube at OSH on [**2-26**], unclear why this was done, will need to contact OSH today to clarify, and continue tube feeds.
* Liver lesions on CT: Anticipate eventual further imaging of liver.
* CAD: Stable, continue BB and ASA, holding statin.
* Anemia: No acute bleed, either Fe def or ACD, trend Hct.
* Afib/SSS: Rate-controlled for now.
* HTN: Holding anti-HTN meds and monitor.
* Met alkalosis: Due to OSH diuresis, no indication for further diuresis at this point, support IVF for now, can repeat ABG today as above to assess degree of alkalemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued respiratory failure can lead to further decline in oxygenation and ventilation, potentially requiring mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Tricuspid vegetation: The patient's history of tricuspid vegetation and unclear risk history may increase the risk of endocarditis, which can lead to further complications such as valve damage, heart failure, or embolic events.
* LUE swelling: The patient's LUE swelling may be a sign of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), which can lead to further complications such as pulmonary infarction, respiratory failure, or cardiac arrest.
* Poss aspiration and hx erosive esophagitis: The patient's history of gastrostomy tube insertion and erosive esophagitis may increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia, which can lead to further respiratory complications.
* Liver lesions on CT: The patient's liver lesions may be a sign of liver disease or metastasis, which can lead to further complications such as liver failure, bleeding, or sepsis.
* CAD: The patient's history of CAD and stable condition may increase the risk of further cardiac events such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrest, or heart failure.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may increase the risk of further complications such as cardiovascular events, respiratory failure, or bleeding.
* Afib/SSS: The patient's atrial fibrillation and SSS may increase the risk of further cardiac events such as stroke, cardiac arrest, or heart failure.
* HTN: The patient's history of HTN and holding anti-HTN meds may increase the risk of further cardiovascular events such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrest, or heart failure.
* Met alkalosis: The patient's met alkalosis may increase the risk of further complications such as respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, or seizures.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including endocarditis, pneumonia, altered mental status, and other comorbidities. Here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a tricuspid valve vegetation, which is likely to be a source of ongoing infection. The patient's cardiologist is concerned about the potential for further complications, including valve damage or embolization.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has been treated for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and is currently on treatment for nosocomial pneumonia. The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of further complications, including respiratory failure or pneumonia progression.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved, but the cause is unclear. The patient's differential diagnosis includes anoxic brain injury, seizure, and post-ictal state. Further evaluation, including an EEG and daily wake-up, is planned.
4. Hypothermia: The patient's temperature is currently normal, but there is a risk of hypothermia due to the patient's underlying medical conditions.
5. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which may be due to contraction alkalosis or other causes. Further evaluation, including an ABG, is planned.
6. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which is poorly controlled. The patient is at risk for further complications, including hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
7. Right Upper Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a suspected DVT, which is currently being treated with therapeutic INR. Further evaluation, including ultrasound and repeat imaging, is planned.
8. Sick Sinus Syndrome: The patient has a paced rhythm, which is currently rate-controlled. The patient is at risk for further complications, including arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
9. Ventricular Dilation: The patient has ventricular dilation, which may be due to underlying heart disease or other causes. Further evaluation, including echocardiogram and cardiac enzymes, is planned.
10. Gastrointestinal issues: The patient has a history of esophagitis and is at risk for further complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.

Potential medical complications that may arise in the patient include:

* Further cardiac complications, such as valve damage or embolization
* Respiratory failure or pneumonia progression
* Seizures or post-ictal state
* Hypothermia or metabolic alkalosis
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia
* DVT progression or pulmonary embolism
* Arrhythmias or cardiac failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
* Further anemia or bleeding complications

Given the patient's complex medical history and ongoing medical issues, it is essential to continue to monitor and manage the patient's condition closely to prevent or minimize potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall, 61.5 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. The patient's cardiologist is concerned about the tricuspid valve vegetation and would like to obtain a TEE for further characterization.

The patient underwent a PICC line placement, transesophageal echocardiogram, ultrasound, and thoracentesis. The patient was extubated successfully, but remains on nasal cannula oxygen and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37C, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/82 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 23 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95%. The patient's neurological status is unchanged, with the patient responding to stimuli but not fully awake.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, and platelet count, with normal kidney function and electrolyte levels. The patient's troponin-T level is 0.04 ng/mL, and the patient's CK, CKMB, and troponin-T levels are normal.

The patient's medical history is significant for previous radiation therapy, erosive esophagitis, and concern for aspiration. The patient's family history is significant for a cardiologist who is familiar with the patient's condition.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Endocarditis: The patient's tricuspid valve vegetation may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, heart failure, or embolic events.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's aspiration pneumonia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure or sepsis.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's confusion may progress to delirium or coma, which could lead to increased risk of falls, aspiration, or other complications.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, but the patient is at risk for hypoglycemia due to the patient's altered mental status and potential for medication errors.
5. DVT: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to immobility and central venous catheter placement.
6. VAP: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to critical illness and potential for gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes continued monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and neurological status. The patient will continue to receive antibiotics for endocarditis and pneumonia, and will be monitored for signs of sepsis or organ failure. The patient's cardiologist will be updated on the patient's condition, and the patient will be considered for further diagnostic testing, such as a TEE.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, pneumonia, and altered mental status. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and chronic kidney disease. He was previously treated for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) at another hospital, but his mental status deteriorated during treatment. He was intubated and received antibiotics, but his mental status remained altered.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He was extubated successfully, but his respiratory status is still being monitored.
* Cardiovascular: He has a tricuspid valve vegetation and a possible myxoma or fibroelastoma on his right atrium. His cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and he is receiving anticoagulation therapy.
* Neurological: His mental status is still altered, but he is responding to commands and able to move all extremities.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a G-tube in place due to esophagitis and concern for aspiration.
* Renal: His creatinine levels are elevated, and he is receiving dialysis.
* Hepatic: He has liver lesions on his CT scan, which need to be further evaluated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's tricuspid valve vegetation and possible myxoma or fibroelastoma on his right atrium increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and embolization.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of respiratory complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible sepsis increase his risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, and brain abscesses.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's G-tube in place and possible aspiration increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration pneumonia and gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and possible acute kidney injury (AKI) increase his risk of renal complications, such as chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
6. Hepatic complications: The patient's liver lesions on his CT scan and possible liver failure increase his risk of hepatic complications, such as liver failure and portal hypertension.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and cardiac function.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his nutrition and hydration as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hepatic function and adjust his liver enzyme levels as needed.
7. Consult with a cardiologist to further evaluate the patient's cardiac condition and develop a plan for cardiac surgery evaluation.
8. Consult with a pulmonologist to further evaluate the patient's respiratory condition and develop a plan for pneumonia treatment.
9. Consult with a gastroenterologist to further evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal condition and develop a plan for esophageal evaluation and treatment.
10. Consult with a nephrologist to further evaluate the patient's renal condition and develop a plan for dialysis and kidney function management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with progressive decline, altered mental status, and pneumonia. The patient has a complex medical history, including endocarditis, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, chronic pancreatitis, and a history of radiation therapy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: The patient's temperature is 37C, heart rate is 65 beats per minute, blood pressure is 98/82 mmHg, respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is on invasive ventilation and has a central venous catheter.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 3,369 mL of fluids and has lost 2,443 mL of fluids, resulting in a positive fluid balance of 926 mL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 8.1 K/uL, hemoglobin is 9.5 g/dL, and platelet count is 610 K/uL. The patient's creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL, and his troponin level is 0.04 ng/mL.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Endocarditis: The patient has a right atrial mass likely caused by a myxoma or fibroelastoma.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been highly variable, and he has required tube feeds and dextrose administration.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been altered, and he has been confused and disoriented.
* Pneumonia: The patient has been treated for community-acquired pneumonia and now has nosocomial pneumonia.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic inflammation.
* Liver lesions: The patient has liver lesions on CT scan, and further evaluation is recommended.
* CAD: The patient has coronary artery disease and is on ASA and metoprolol.
* Hypertension: The patient has hypertension and is on metoprolol.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism and is on levothyroxine.
* Chronic pancreatitis: The patient has chronic pancreatitis and is on Creon with meals and tube feeds.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia
* Tube feeds and nutrition consultation
* Monitoring of blood glucose levels
* Management of hypertension and hypothyroidism
* Evaluation of liver lesions and potential liver dysfunction
* Further evaluation of the patient's mental status and potential causes of altered mental status
* Consideration of extubation and weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Management of fluid balance and electrolyte levels
* Monitoring of the patient's cardiovascular status and potential cardiac complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old man who was transferred from another hospital with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was extubated yesterday and had a thoracentesis procedure. He has been experiencing some confusion, low blood sugars, and wheezing overnight. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure of 140/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. His respiratory support includes a nasal cannula and PSV/SBT mode on the ventilator.

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. He also has a tricuspid vegetation that is suspicious for a tumor, and he has liver lesions on CT scan. He is being treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and other medications as needed.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.
2. Tricuspid valve disease: The patient's tricuspid vegetation is suspicious for a tumor, which could lead to further complications if not properly managed.
3. Liver disease: The patient's liver lesions on CT scan could indicate liver disease, which could lead to further complications if not properly managed.
4. Bleeding risk: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and recent thoracentesis procedure increase his risk of bleeding, which could lead to complications if not properly monitored.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and recent thoracentesis procedure increase his risk of infection, which could lead to further complications if not properly managed.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypertension increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or stroke.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's tube feeds and recent respiratory failure may increase his risk of nutritional deficiencies, which could lead to further complications if not properly managed.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

The patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred from the operating room to the ICU with progressive pneumonia and acute respiratory failure. He was extubated yesterday and is currently receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula. He has been experiencing low blood glucose levels and some confusion overnight. He denies shortness of breath or pain. His physical examination is significant for right lower extremity edema, which is absent on the left. His laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, and his chest X-ray shows left lung infiltrates.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may progress and lead to further complications such as sepsis or respiratory failure.
3. Tricuspid valve vegetation: The patient's tricuspid valve vegetation may lead to further complications such as endocarditis or embolization.
4. Liver lesions: The patient's liver lesions may be a sign of underlying liver disease or cancer, and further imaging is needed to determine the cause.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further complications such as stroke or heart failure.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may lead to further complications such as heart failure, stroke, or kidney disease.
7. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes may lead to further complications such as ketoacidosis, hypoglycemia, or nephropathy.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may lead to further complications such as bleeding or bruising.

Plan:

1. Continue oxygen therapy via nasal cannula.
2. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
3. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia.
4. Monitor the patient's tricuspid valve vegetation and consider further imaging or intervention if necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's liver lesions and consider further imaging or biopsy if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac arrhythmias and consider further intervention if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hypertension and consider further intervention if necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's diabetes and consider further intervention if necessary.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and consider further intervention if necessary.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall, 63.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, pneumonia, and shock. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a CMV/ASSIST mode, with a set tidal volume of 430 mL, respiratory rate of 24, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. They are also receiving vasopressor support with norepinephrine at 0.05 mcg/Kg/min.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 35.9C, heart rate 79 bpm, blood pressure 108/49 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98%. Their hemodynamic monitoring reveals a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 54-63%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 17.7 K/uL, hemoglobin of 28.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 481 K/uL. Their blood cultures are pending.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their altered mental status, and their skin, peripheral vascular, and neurologic examinations are not assessed.

The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, and they have a known allergy to vancomycin.

The patient's plan includes continued ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and their white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an infection.
2. Shock: The patient is currently receiving vasopressor support, which may indicate ongoing hypotension.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of pneumonia, which may worsen if not properly treated.
4. Endocarditis: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and they have a known allergy to vancomycin, which may indicate endocarditis.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are not well-controlled, which may lead to hypoglycemia.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if not properly managed.
7. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which may increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
8. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to their prolonged immobility and mechanical ventilation.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications and to improve their clinical outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with cardiac arrest. He remains intubated and sedated, but has not woken up. His cardiac function has decreased, with an EF of 45% compared to 55% pre-arrest. He has mild global hypokinesis on echo. He has been receiving vasopressors to maintain MAP and has been weaned off sedation. His blood cultures are pending, and he has been started on antibiotics. He has also been diagnosed with ARDS and is receiving treatment accordingly.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and he has been started on antibiotics, which increases the risk of sepsis.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac function has decreased, and he has mild global hypokinesis on echo, which may indicate a higher risk of cardiac complications.
3. Respiratory Complications: The patient has ARDS and is receiving treatment accordingly, which may increase the risk of respiratory complications.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may indicate a higher risk of neurological complications.
5. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient is requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP, which may indicate hemodynamic instability.
6. Infection: The patient has a PICC line, which increases the risk of infection.
7. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT, which may increase the risk of further clotting.
8. Stress Ulcer: The patient has a history of stress ulcer, which may increase the risk of bleeding.
9. VAP: The patient has a history of VAP, which may increase the risk of further respiratory complications.
10. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of hypoglycemia, which may increase the risk of further hypoglycemic episodes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU after experiencing a progressive decline, including aspiration pneumonia, altered mental status, and recurrent pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient remains intubated and is being treated for sepsis, respiratory failure, and hypotension.

The patient's condition is complex, and multiple potential medical complications can arise. Some of these complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to the aspiration pneumonia and may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 200, indicating severe respiratory failure. Further deterioration may lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely related to sepsis, sedating medications, and cardiac dysfunction. Further deterioration may lead to organ failure.
4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and decreased cardiac output.
5. Tricuspid valve mass: The patient has a tricuspid valve mass that is not an acute issue, but further evaluation and management are necessary.
6. Hepatic lesions: The patient has hepatic lesions that require further evaluation and management.
7. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia requires further evaluation and management.
9. Chronic pancreatitis: The patient's chronic pancreatitis requires further evaluation and management.
10. Erosive esophagitis: The patient's erosive esophagitis requires further evaluation and management.

Given the patient's complex condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his sepsis, respiratory failure, and hypotension. The patient's family should be kept informed of his condition and treatment plan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old gentleman who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing a cardiac arrest. The patient has a history of chronic conditions, including diabetes, chronic pancreatitis, and hypertension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 430 mL and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% on 40% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and is receiving heparin therapy. The patient's blood pressure is currently 108/49 mmHg, and the patient is receiving vasopressor support with norepinephrine.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status and is sedated on propofol. The patient has had some anoxic injury and has purposeful movements following intubation.
* Renal: The patient has a urinary catheter in place and is receiving IV fluids.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a nasogastric tube in place and is receiving tube feeds.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia and is receiving iron therapy.
* Hepatobiliary: The patient has liver lesions and is receiving antifungal therapy.

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 46 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 108 mEq/L
* Creatinine: 137 mEq/L
* Glucose: 46 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L
* LDH: 302 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.0 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.7 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis: The patient's lactate level is elevated, and the patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Aspiration: The patient has had an aspiration event, and the patient is at risk for further aspiration.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for further infection.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and is at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient is at risk for further renal damage.
* Hepatic failure: The patient has liver lesions and is at risk for further liver damage.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Continued vasopressor support
* Continued antibiotics
* Monitoring of lactate level and cardiac enzymes
* Monitoring of renal function
* Monitoring of liver function
* Monitoring of gastrointestinal bleeding
* Consideration of further diagnostic tests, such as echocardiogram and CT scan of the liver.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 68-year-old man with a history of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL) and remote mantle XRT with subsequent esophageal stricture, recurrent aspiration after PEG insertion on [**2171-2-26**]. He was readmitted to the MICU after a PEA arrest and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: probable aspiration with GNRs in sputum from [**3-3**]
* Shock: presumed septic shock given aspiration history; no evidence of cardiogenic shock at this point
* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: probable aspiration
* Obtundation: despite sedation hold; will assess off sedation today
* Recurrent aspiration: failed bedside swallow yesterday; continued aspiration of tube feeds
* Hematuria: hx of foley trauma, reosolving
* Tricuspid valve mass: CT consulted; not an acute issue
* Hepatic lesions: f/u final read of multiphasic CT scan of the liver
* Diarrhea: check C diff
* Hypoglycemia: cut Lantus dose in half

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: further aspiration or development of pneumonia
2. Septic shock: progression of sepsis with organ dysfunction
3. Cardiogenic shock: development of cardiac failure
4. Hemodynamic instability: continued hypotension or hypertension
5. Neurological compromise: further obtundation or development of cerebral edema
6. Infection: development of secondary infections such as pneumonia or sepsis
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: further bleeding from esophageal stricture or other sources
8. Renal failure: worsening kidney function due to hypovolemia or sepsis
9. Metabolic derangements: further hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the goals of care should be discussed with the family and the patient's wishes should be respected.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL) and remote mantle radiation therapy (XRT) with subsequent esophageal stricture. He was readmitted to the MICU after a PEA arrest and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient is currently sedated and unable to provide a history. He has a persistent hypoglycemia requiring repeated D50 boluses and is unable to wean from norepinephrine despite approximately 10L of resuscitation.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. PEA arrest: likely due to hypoxemic respiratory failure from aspiration.
2. Shock: presumed septic shock given the patient's aspiration history and lack of evidence of cardiogenic shock.
3. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: probable aspiration with Gram-negative rods (GNRs) in sputum.
4. Obtundation: despite sedation hold, the patient's level of consciousness remains altered.
5. Recurrent aspiration: failed bedside swallow with continued aspiration of tube feeds.
6. Hematuria: likely due to Foley trauma, resolving.
7. Tricuspid valve mass: a non-acute issue, requiring further evaluation.
8. Hepatic lesions: requiring further evaluation.
9. Diarrhea: potentially due to Clostridium difficile (C. diff).
10. Hypoglycemia: requiring adjustment of insulin therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: given the patient's aspiration history and suspected septic shock.
2. Pneumonia: possible aspiration pneumonia with GNRs in sputum.
3. Respiratory failure: continued hypoxemic respiratory failure with potential for further deterioration.
4. Cardiac complications: potential for cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to sepsis or hypoxia.
5. Renal failure: potential for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypoperfusion or sepsis.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: potential for further gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to aspiration or sepsis.
7. Infections: potential for further infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections (UTIs), or bloodstream infections (BSIs).
8. Neurological complications: potential for further neurological deterioration due to hypoxia, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
9. Cardiovascular complications: potential for cardiac arrest or arrhythmias due to hypoxia, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
10. Hematological complications: potential for further bleeding or clotting disorders due to sepsis, hypoxia, or other underlying conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall, 63.1 kg individual who is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and their vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7C (98.1F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 140/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.5-20.5 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 540-578 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.8-1.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.03-0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 28-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 173-223 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Shock, possibly hypovolemic or hemorrhagic
* Endocarditis, possibly due to a prosthetic valve
* Hypoglycemia
* Altered mental status, not due to delirium
* Pneumonia, possibly aspiration

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg IV
* Vancomycin and piperacillin antibiotics
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Midazolam (Versed) for sedation
* Fentanyl for pain management

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient's neurologic examination is also limited due to their altered mental status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of shock or endocarditis
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia
* Pneumonia or aspiration
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Stress ulcer bleeding
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   A 68 yo gentleman with progressive decline transferred from [**Location (un) 11374**]
   after PNA/AMS with an acute change in mental status with recurrent
   aspiration PNA / PEA arrest, regained pulse now intubated.
   # PEA Arrest:  need further assessment of neurologic status.
   -stop continuous EEG monitoring
   -monitor neurologic status.
   -continue periodic family mtgs to discuss prognosis
   .
   # Aspiration PNA / respiratory failure:
   -continue to hold tube feeds pending post pyloric tube placement
   -PaO2/FiO2 ratio 200, continue current vent settings and continue to
   monitor
   -continue vanc/zosyn (day 1 = [**3-6**], day [**3-3**])
   - Wean peep as tolerated
   .
   # Hypotension: continue levophed.  Likely related to sepsis as well as
   sedating medications.  Wean sedation as above.
   - restart bb in am if stable overnight
   .
   # Afib with RVR: currently well rate controlled HR 90 off of lopressor,
   - held heparin for hematuria, however stable will restart without bolus
   - warfarin in AM if stable overnight
   - continue to hold given hypotension
   # [**Last Name (un) 2406**]: likely multifactorial, secondary to hypotension during arrest,
   contrast load, etc.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - diuresis goal
 1.5L today
   # leukocytosis: continue to monitor for infection, would consider c
   diff workup
   .
   # Tricuspid valve mass:   CT [**Doctor First Name **] consulted.  Not acute issue.  F/u CT
   [**Doctor First Name **] recs.
   # Hepatic lesions: outpatient follow up.
   # Hematuria: Likely foley trauma in setting of heparin gtt.
   - continue to monitor, flush prn, when extubated can remove foley
   # Diabetes Mellitus: hold tube feeds, decrease lantus to 2  units qhs
   and sliding scale.
   # Anemia: Iron studies c/w ACD.
   - cont. to monitor
   #CAD:
   - cont. metoprolol and ASA, heparin drip for afib
   # Chronic pancreatitis:
   - cont. Creon with meals/tube feeds.
